conclusion: Introduction to the problem of a concealed lock with self-locking phenomenon.
Understanding the components of the lock from Figure A.
Description of Housing A, Frame B, Spring C, Latch D, and Lock groove E.
Inclination angle θ = 30° and dynamic friction coefficient μ are given.
In Figure B, the lock is shown in a top view with latch compressed by distance x and contact point P.
Self-locking state implies frictional forces prevent latch movement.
Need to find the normal force F_N between latch D and lock groove E.
Forces acting on latch D include Spring Force, Normal Force, and Frictional Force.
Spring Force F_s = kx acts to extend the latch.
Normal Force F_N is perpendicular to lock groove's surface.
Frictional Force F_f resists latch motion, F_f = μF_N.
System in self-locking state implies forces are in equilibrium.
Horizontal components of forces must balance each other.
Spring force F_s is horizontal, normal force F_N is at angle 30° from vertical.
Clarification on inclination angle and normal force direction.
Normal force F_N is at angle 90° + θ from horizontal.
Horizontal component of F_N is F_N * cos θ, vertical component is -F_N * sin θ.
Frictional force F_f acts along surface, opposing spring force.
In self-locking position, spring pushes latch left, friction opposes.
Net force is zero due to equilibrium.
Horizontal forces: Spring force F_s = kx (left), Frictional force F_f = μF_N (right).
Equilibrium implies kx - μF_N = 0.
Normal force F_N = kx / μ.
